div.p:
your very undeserving friend begs to intrude on your
Observe I only mean undeserving in the way of letter writing for
as to sentiments of true regard and friends Damon and Pithias
Pylades and Orestes and all the other models of friendly
regard were a joke to me. But it is a world to see how long
I will sometimes be in writing to them I must respect and hon-
ourhonourhonor and how often I want in doing what I ought to do till I
get some thrust or push operating like a flapper to compel me
to my duty. The flapper on this occasion is the departure of a
young friend of mine Count Davidoff DavidowDavydov a Russian of
high rank and very considerable observation and talent who
proposes visiting Green Ireland. For his time of life you will
find he has collected a great deal of information and now
with much advantage the various opportunities which his ex-
tensiveextensive travels have afforded him. He has been a good deal
with me at Abbotsford and will bring you news of our
household. The gentlemen who travels with him is Mr.
Colyer a Catholic young DavidoffDavydov himself is of the Greek Church
He does not take his title of Count but remains a simple
Mister.

Well how is a new world in politics - will it be a better
one - Who dare answer the question, I have a great confidence
in fortune and hope for the best. I suppose you will soon
get the Catholic question which will be our grievance out of the

list Green Erin has to show. After all though the worst will remain
and I have some doubt withe whether Ireland may not be like
the old Frenchman who regretted being cured of his tape-worm which
supplied him with a certain degree of interesting employment by
in order to wind an inch of it up every day. Now here is the
Catholic emancipation occupies every eye and ear and folks endure
worse evils because they hope that carrying this power will operate
as an universal panacea.

I wrote to you acquainting you with the mishap of the little
terrier which was carried off by what is emphatically called
The Distemper which is particularly fatal to dogs of high blood
It was inoculation that is vaccinated but all efforts were
in vain All my other dogs are well only Nimrod the great
wolf-dog has worried my ancient domestic cat which was
great a loss to me as it would have been to Robinson Crusoe.

How often I think of Ireland and all the fine scenery
I saw there, aye and all the never to be forgotten kindness of
the inhabitants above all at the hospitable Edgeworths townEdgeworthstown.
But I am inclined to quarrel with its most distinguished
inhabitants for wasting or rather hiding under a napkin her
fine talent and ceasing to amuse us with as some tale
which nobody dare tell but herself. You should not be
the manners and peculiarities of Ireland which it is of so much
importance that the legislature ought to be acquainted with. You
have already shewn us the kindness talent and disinterested
fidelity of the Crown orders in Ireland. Do a little more and shewshow
us how to cure the evils which prevent them rising in the scale of
society possessed as they are of so much that is amiable and excellent
Why is it the poor Irish should fill all the hard and laborious
duties not only in England but now even in Scotland for within
this ten years the Irish have occupied almost all the ballast-
heaving

hod-carrying canal digging kind of work at which the inhabitants will
not work so cheap because they must observe certain decencies of apparel
and possess some comfort in their mode of living. Pat is so good a nag
that I cannot help thinking you would be able to find some bridle
which would suit him and admit his being ridden with a light hand
with all deference to scientific researches into the philosophy of mechan
icalmechanical pursuits I think you could do so much for us in showing
is how to mend the worst part of our British machine
Here being interrupted by the necessity of packing and
having my papers to put to rights ommitted save in case of absolute neces
sitynecessity, I finish the enclosed half letter written to you on the subject of
the dog which has never it seems been sent How that has happened
as Paddy O Rourke says is hard to determine My recollection was that
it was sent off However I enclose it as her official document of the
vague events so my letter will be a letter for a half a Scottish
mode of expressing any thing that is very extraordinary,
BoneparteBonaparte draws on to a conclusion but I fear will with the necessary
new documents which I design to print run on to at least
nine volumes for though I have won the battle of Waterloo There
is much remains behind. I must not blink Saint Helena
the most unpleasant part of the work
Beg your kind mother and Mrs Sneyd to accept my love
and the invalid who is I hope one no longer - to Mrs Lane Fox and
Mrs Butler & Mr Butler (and some of you a rolling this year
I believe Lockhart will be with us at Abbotsford so with
Beatrices assistance and a few rough cuts from the "Poor
wounded Hussar" who is just come to England as caught up
a goodnatured My kind Compliments to the Squire and to
your brother
William my kind Killarney pilot Always
Abbot Edinh. 15 May
